metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof PREVENTION AND PROTECTION MEASURES OF HEALTHCARE WORKERS EXPOSED IN HEALTH SETTINGS TO SEVERE ACUTE RESPIRATORY INFECTIONS FROM SARS-COV-2 IN A UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL IN BARI, APULIA REGION, SOUTHERN ITALY PREVENTION AND PROTECTION MEASURES OF HEALTHCARE WORKERS EXPOSED IN HEALTH SETTINGS TO SEVERE ACUTE RESPIRATORY INFECTIONS FROM SARS-COV-2 IN A UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL IN BARI, APULIA REGION, SOUTHERN ITALY

abstract.text: SARS-CoV-2-related SARIs (severe acute respiratory infections) have a major impact on public health; moreover, healthcare workers (HCWs) are exposed to a high biological risk. The aim of this study was to show the prevention procedures in place in the University Hospital of Bari (Apulia Region, Southern Italy) to reduce this risk to HCWs, consisting of the enhancement of preventive measures and the activation of a report system to collect HCWs' contacts. To date, 23 confirmed cases of infections (0.4% of all HCWs) have been reported in a 30-day observation period. These results show that correct management of HCWs' contacts is essential to avoid nosocomial clusters.

body_text.text: The World Health Organization (WHO) states that SARI (severe acute respiratory infection) is an acute respiratory infection associated with fever (>38°C), cough onset (or re-exacerbation in COPD patients) and other pulmonary symptoms that starts at most within ten days before admission to the hospital and requires hospitalization [1].

Sometimes, SARIs can become a public health emergency; this happens when a pathogen (frequently a virus) gains high virulence, spreading through populations in many countries on different continents (pandemics). Throughout history, influenza virus type A, belonging to the Orthomyxoviridae family, have caused pandemics, but in recent times, retroviruses belonging to the Coronavirinae family have also been shown to be able to cause SARI outbreaks due to their lower respiratory tract epithelium tropism. In 2002-2003, SARS-CoV infected 8096 people and killed 774, while MERS-CoV has infected 2494 people and killed 858 since 2012 [2] . Recently, on 9

January 2020, the Chinese Centers for Disease Control (CDC) identified a novel coronavirus known as SARS-CoV-2. On 3 March 2020, the WHO has affirmed that the SARS-CoV-2 infection had become pandemic; multiple infection routes (via the respiratory route, contact with fomites, and probably also faecal-oral) and high contagiousness [3] , with the highest estimated R 0 of 4.6, seem to be essential factors for this global outbreak.
To date, over two-thirds of Italian SARS-CoV-2 cases have been grouped in four northern regions; climatic factors and particulate matter (PM) levels may play a role in promoting viral spread.
Indeed, PM is known to be able to transfer small pathogens from the upper to lower respiratory tract [4] .

Due to the high contagiousness of SARS-CoV-2, healthcare professionals are occupationally exposed to high biological risk; however, Cheng et al. [5] demonstrated that correct use of PPE by the healthcare staff of Hong Kong's hospitals was associated with no cases of infection during a 42day period of observation.

The aim of this study was to describe the preventive protocol for SARS-CoV-2-related SARIs executed out by the Operative Unit of Occupational Medicine among HCWs in the University Hospital of Bari, Apulia Region, Southern Italy.

Our preventive protocol was implemented and was based on the latest guidelines published by the World Health Organization (WHO) [6] . Current ECDC definitions of suspected, probable and confirmed cases were adopted, as well as the assessments of "close contact" and "casual contact" [7] , to identify healthcare workers (HCWs) exposed to a significant biological risk. This protocol has been applied for all 5750 HCWs working at University Hospital in a 30-day observation period after protocol activation (21 February 2020). All HCWs were informed about the research protocol and its purpose.

General hygienic practices (e.g., handshake avoidance, frequent air changes in rooms, physical separation of suspected infected patients, room disinfection and overcrowding avoidance) have been reinforced among both HCWs and users. Moreover, appropriate utilization of personal protective equipment (PPE) has been implemented. In this regard, all HCWs were educated about correct donning and doffing procedures carried out in the anteroom before and after making contact with suspected or confirmed cases and were guided by warning signs to correctly perform the actions.

A reporting system was activated to collect and monitor all HCW contact with cases with suspected or confirmed SARS-CoV-2. Reports started from an HCW that had contact: he/she informed the head physician of their hospital wards, who in turn alerted a central control room, known as the COVID-19 Control Room, and the Operative Unit of Occupational Medicine. The Operative Unit of Occupational Medicine evaluated the clinical conditions and undertook virological assessment of each HCW to consider their resumption of work, as described in Figure 1 .

HCWs who had "close contact with a confirmed case without PPE" were temporally suspended from work for a 7-day period. Hospitalization was not required if their clinical condition was good; rather, only home isolation was required under the control of the Prevention Department outside of the hospital, which briefed the COVID-19 Control Room and Operative Unit of Occupational Medicine about workers' conditions and, on the last day, performed nasopharyngeal swabs. A molecular test was performed for all workers who became symptomatic. Positive HCWs were not allowed to return to work until they were clinically and virologically cured; the latter was defined as double molecular test negativity in a 24-hour period.

If an HCW tested negative for SARS-CoV-2, he/she was allowed to return to work but would be subjected to active surveillance to detect early new symptoms suggestive of SARS-CoV-2 (ageusia, anosmia, fever, cough, myalgia weakness, dyspnoea, migraine), since a window of a few days is described for this infection.

HCWs who had "close contact with a suspected case without PPE" were suspended from work, and the suspected case underwent a swab test. If the patient was negative, the worker was allowed to return to work. If the case was confirmed as COVID-19 the HCW followed the protocol for "close contact with a confirmed case without PPE".

HCWs who had "close contact with PPE" were always reported to the Control Room, but workers were allowed to work, and only self-monitoring was recommended for a 14-day period, as medical viral clearance is thought to be approximately 11 days in symptomatic patients and shorter in asymptomatic patients [8] . A swab test was performed if workers became symptomatic: negative HCWs were allowed to go back to work, and positive HCWs were suspended from work until clinical and virological cure was documented.

Equally, HCWs who had "casual contact" were allowed to work, but self-monitoring was strongly recommended. In case of symptoms, the management protocol was identical to the protocol utilized for "close contact with PPE".

HCWs allowed to work had to avoid the workplace if they became symptomatic during their shift (fever, cough, myalgia weakness, short breath, migraine) in a 14-day period after exposure; they also had to warn the Control Room and Operating Unit of Occupational Medicine of their symptoms. Instead, if symptoms started at home, workers had to warn the prevention departments outside the hospital, which in turn had to alert Control Room and Operating Unit of Occupational Medicine. These HCWs underwent rapid swab testing: the adopted protocol after the swab result was identical to those for HCWs who had "close contact with PPE".

After protocol activation, all notified HCWs' close contacts were recorded, and every case was scanned and verified by the COVID-19 Control Room and Operative Unit of Occupational Medicine. From the beginning of the epidemic in Italy (21 st February 2020) to date, 7033 nasopharyngeal swabs were performed on hospital users, referred to pre-triage of the emergency department. These tests were justified by epidemiological (close contacts) and clinical (ageusia, anosmia, cough, fever, myalgia, weakness or SARI symptoms) criteria. Among the tests, 1065 were positive (15.14%), and 5968 were negative (84.86%). All involved workers reported contact modalities with these patients to the control room through the reporting system. Contacts of employees were also collected. Based on these reports, 560 HCWs' contact tracing complete forms were collected to determine all people who had contact with these workers. Moreover, based on the illustrated decision-making process in Figure 1 , 1303 swabs were performed in the hospital setting during a 30-day observation period due to the high HCWs' close contact risk assessment. Of these, only 16 (1.38%) swabs were positive (2 after the second confirming test). Moreover, regarding swabs performed in home isolation by the Prevention Department, the other 7 HCWs were positive and communicated with the COVID-19 Control Room. Overall, 23 HCWs were infected by SARS-CoV-2, with an average age of 48.6 years. Among these, 16 were physicians (2 of whom were in training), 5 were nurses and 2 were social health assistants (SAHs). Regarding the most commonly reported symptoms, weakness was present in 72% of workers, diarrhoea in 60%, cough in 56% and fever in 52%. Almost half of infected HCWs complained about anosmia and ageusia, and these were referred to as the most common disorders.

To date, the prevalence of SARS-CoV-2 infection is 0.4% among all HCWs working in the University Hospital of Bari in a 30-day observation period after protocol activation (23 workers on 5750 subjected to protocol) (Table I) .

These results are likely due to the adoption of correct prevention measures focused on infection source control, administrative strategies, environmental control and correct PPE utilization associated with ancillary hygienic measures to avoid overcrowding, e.g., reducing the number of HCWs in rooms hosting suspected and/or confirmed cases, organizing in advance the needed bedside medical and surgical procedures, using PPE only until maximum usage time, and the performance of nasopharyngeal swabs only by one HCW per working shift.

Moreover, establishing preventive protocols is essential to provide safe guidance to HCWs and consequently reduce their work-related stress, which is a known factor able to influence work performance [9] . The reporting system is also essential to prevent nosocomial outbreaks from HCWs: reports through this platform have been mandatory both for professional and environmental close contacts. In our protocol, the COVID-19 Control Room has a central role to cooperate with extra-hospital Prevention Departments about suspected and confirmed cases of HCWs placed in home isolation; it also provides to evaluate all people who had contact previously with involved HCW and it ordains domiciliary nasopharyngeal swabs. It would be good to monitor all patients who in the hospital setting have had contacts with involved HCWs by their hospital wards for a 14day period; instead, if patients have been discharged from the hospital, they should be monitored in home isolation by the Prevention Department. Compliance with all appropriate prevention procedures, together with detailed reporting systems, are crucial to avoid hospital outbreaks and yo achieve a very low prevalence among HCWs. In this regard, Wang et al. [10] , in a retrospective single-centre case series of approximately 138 COVID-19 patients, estimated that 29% were HCWs working in the same hospital centre and infected during shifts due to occupational exposure to infected patients, compared with 0.4% during our observation period. In this regard, half of positive HCWs complained about ageusia and anosmia: they seem to be early symptoms, if present, and so great attention should be given to there from the outset. HCWs occupationally exposed to SARS-CoV-2 should be aware of the strategic importance of referring any close contact to the hospital management system, with a subsequent careful focus on all secondary contacts. Moreover, ward managers should ensure that there is effective performance of self-monitoring procedures, with particular regard to HCWs subjected to active surveillance.

In conclusion, our protocol has given good results in our hospital, with only 23 HCWs infected by SARS-CoV-2 amongst 1303 performed swabs. However, these results are based only on swab execution after accurate risk assessment; further studies are needed to understand the effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 immunity among HCWs.
Funding source: This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial or no-for-profit sectors.

Ethics approval and consent to participate: Informed and written consent was obtained from all participants. All subjects were informed that data from the research protocol would be treated in an anonymous and collective way, with scientific methods and for scientific purposes in accordance with the principles of the Helsinki Declaration. Ethical approval is not necessary because all medical and instrumental examinations were performed according to Italian law concerning the protection of workers exposed to occupational risks (D.Lgs. 81/2008).
